review_title: Disappointing to see the most recent reviews - not a true reflection of Refuge
pros: The work we do has real value to survivors, every role and every department plays a part. We are busy and caseloads are high I think the emphasis needs to be on the commissioners to plug the gap. We have a very high performing development and fundraising team that can only do so much. The recent reports are disappointing and while everybody has their own views, I think it is important to note what an individual feels in a service will not necessarily be a reflection on Refuge as a whole. Senior managers and HR can only do so much, if people do not report the problems they cannot tackle them. There is much better communication and SLT make an effort to provide time for staff to share their views and feelings.
cons: Workloads often lead to times of stress, I can see why this causes burnout and we lose good people from the organisation.

review_title: Avoid until there is a total overhaul of senior management
pros: Nice offices (although paid for by donations!) great cause and frontline and helpline staff fantastic - supportive colleagues.
cons:
Please google the recent article in the Times for more in depth reasons to avoid Refuge. The main one has to be the bullying, oppressive culture fostered at head office by the CEO and long standing senior management. In one year an entire department left as a result of the awful culture and bullying. The CEO has founders syndrome, and thinks she can run a charity like a private business. Friends and family of hers are hired without interview and are kept on the payrol with access to sensitive information despite living in different countries. CEO expenses are outrageous and not challenged at all - think plane tickets! The CEO used a member of staff to rewrite her book which contains the refuge logo and is promoted on the charity website - but all the proceeds go directly to her pocket. 

Whilst I was there I saw strong, intelligent women who were excellent at their jobs get belittled by senior management in front of the entire office, I was repeatedly told not to do anything without checking it with senior managers (including sending external emails!) this made my job almost impossible and there was no recognition of this at all. There is a culture of fear and control and I would avoid at all costs.

pros: Refuge is an amazing organisation to work with, strong female leadership with the safety and empowerment of women and children at the heart of every decision made. I have been with Refuge since 2012 and during that time have worked in many roles across a range of services and have experienced great opportunities for career progression, supported each and every step of the way by colleagues and senior management. Refuge staff from the CEO (SH), senior management, middle management, front line staff, peer mentors and volunteers all go above and beyond for the cause that we support – not because we are told to, but because each and every one of us is dedicated and passionate about the work we do and the services we provide. This compassion and care is not only directed at the women we support (over 6000 on any given day) but to each and every colleague. I am so very proud to be a manager for Refuge, I am proud of the service we provide, proud of my team and the dedication I see every single day and I am humbled by the senior management teams who support me on a daily basis.
cons: I was totally blind-sighted by the newly appointed chair - Hetti-Barkworth Nanton of Ploughshare Innovations Limited. This in itself seems to directly oppose the very ethos of Refuge on a number of levels; primarily any connection to the weapons industry is not compatible when we know that the biggest victims in any war / conflict is always women and children … women and children, the group that Refuge has fought to support so passionately since the 1970’s. Hetti-Barkworth Nanton has publicly stated that she is not a feminist; Refuge has a solid behaviours framework in place which strongly reinforces the necessity of having a feminist ethos at the heart of the organisation.

review_title: Amazing charity working with amazing people
pros:
This organisation is full of committed and professional staff at all levels who are passionate about ending domestic violence and supporting survivors and their children to find safety and have fulfilling lives. People genuinely care about survivors and will do everything within their power to make sure their rights are upheld.

The training is excellent both in house and through funding specialist external qualifications.

There are opportunities to develop, specialise and grow and I have learned so much during my time with this organisation. 

Feminism is at the heart of the work - equality of the sexes and the establishment of the political, social, and economic rights of the female sex - what right minded person could disagree with that?
cons:
Not so much cons but my personal observation - There are high expectations of staff because the organisation wants to deliver the best possible service to the clients and that does mean that staff go the extra mile for charity level salaries - these are set ultimately by the funders of the contracts and not by Refuge. Some frontline staff and all operational managers are on call out of normal office hours because our clients need help 24/7 so we are there 24/7. 

It is human nature to want to to tell people when you have a bad experience and generally happy staff wont seek out Glassdoor to say how great their experience has been. I hope that the recent publicity about the appointment of a chair of trustees whose employment history and values are at odds with our work, which is what brought me to this site, will do the same for the hundreds of Refuge employees who enjoy their work and are proud of the organisation they work for.

Refuge is not perfect and I am sure that there will be genuine people on here who have not been happy in their employment and have a right to be heard.

I hope that refuge worker salaries can be increased to demonstrate the value of these critical roles, that a way can be found to reduce the frequency that some service managers are on call, that commissioners will realise that well resourced contracts provide great outcomes for survivors and support the wellbeing of the staff who deliver them. I also hope that SMT and board will start to reflect the amazing diversity we have in the rest of the organisation for everyone's benefit.

review_title: Good work to do, but they won't support you
pros: You get the opportunity to help people in need and that is very special. I was able to make a real difference to the lives of so many women and children, at some of the hardest times of their lives, and that was a huge tick in a life box for me.  We were part of a network of professionals who help people at times of crisis and it made me extremely proud.  I am still proud of the work I got the chance to do there and the difference I was able to make.  Ex clients rang back all the time asking for me.  The reviews of senior staff here are often negative and whether that is true or not, I believe wholeheartedly that ALL the women working there wanted the best for the service users and cared passionately about women's issues.  I will never forget some of the people I met, both service users and staff, and I still define myself as a DV advisor. Also the training is very very good; industry leading experts giving you the latest expertise, some of which (like legal changes) would positively affect your service users right then and there.
cons:
Managers don't stick up for their staff. If a resident doesn't turn up for 8 out 10 keywork sessions and then complains that you didn't help them, they will stick up for them, or if they make allegations about staff, they will be believed even when not true. I understand that hurt people hurt people, but I'd say the staff get hurt too and not all allegations are true, but head office will believe them anyway, so at times I observed myself and others feel we just couldn't win and were at risk doing the work.

It became clear to me pretty early on that head office was to be avoided and head kept below parapet. I think the office politics are really bad there, whereas in the projects we had no bad vibes at all and worked very well together.

My main gripe was that the work is really hardcore, but yet managers will just heap more and more and more on you. New residents are traumatised; they need you every day and heap story after story of abuse and heartache and unbelievably bad things onto you.  It is hard to cope with.  On top of this, you have managers at head office thinking of ways the service can improve and who has to do it?  The staff.  On top of everything else.  'Do this. Oh we forgot this idea; do it again. Oh yes, and this!! Yes, for all 96 clients you saw the last quarter.' No matter if residents are knocking on the door in tears, you're expected to redo work and tick little boxes. I really did feel like the staff were not respected and the reality of the role not understood.

In the end I'd say I kind of disliked the organisation while loving helping the clients, but the level of work was having a negative affect on me and periodically I would see incidents unfold where managers took against staff incorrectly, and I just felt alone in the role, and at risk from it.  Yes I felt at risk from the work and knew I would not be supported if push came to shove.  I felt hurt by that, after all the hard work I did for 11 years.  The organisation is true to its' service users, but not to its' staff.  This makes it good to use as a service, but not very good to work for really.  Let's hope they change this.
